column4: There are four different network environments where I use my laptop. What's the best way to autodetect and autoconfigure the settings according to the environment?
install networkmanager
are all four environments wireless?
ok. so why do you need different setup for the three cabled locations?
plug in, get dhcp-lease, start working.
one is static IP (work), one DHCP (home) and one is no-net (on the train).
the fourth is wireless DHCP.
take a look at network manager (sudo apt-cache show network-manager). If that's the same as NetworkManager in Fedora, it's just what you're looking for I think
it's in Universe, btw
thanks, I just installed it.
the network setup tool in breezy actually has "locations" functionality, but I have no idea how to set it up
I've tried locations, it never seems to do what I expect. Also, it's not automatic.
automatic is difficult to do, I think. Unless you can do something you can configure with grub. But then you'd have to boot every time you change locations
but why is the train no-net? ;) I am online 3 hours on the train every day
whenever I boot in a new location, I have trouble with gnome-session. So I login on a text console, run a script to exchange /etc/network/interfaces and /etc/resolv.conf... annoying.
on-train-line?
enter your hostname as an alias to 127.0.0.1 in /etc/hosts
then your hostname is always resolvable
I just assumed that it was...
and gnome-session will not have problems. I alternate between work (cabled), train (gprs/edge) and home (wlan) without any trouble with gnome-session
how do you connect to GPRS, via a phone or PCMCIA card?
phone. bluetooth. So I just keep my phone in my pocket and dial.
use the gnome-ppp for dialing.
back in a few minutes...
